creator: cowwoc@bbs.darktech.org
text:
In the Tomcat Configuration Manager, Log On tab, I enter a username/password for
Tomcat to run as. When I restart the configuration manager the settings revert
to Log on as "local system account". If I try launching Tomcat anyway I can see
it runs as the SYSTEM user so it is clear my settings are getting lost.

The problem is caused by the fact that the specified user did not have a "run as
a service" permission and this needed to be added by the config manager. If one
configures the Tomcat service directly and try configuring the "run as" user
account then windows will pop up a window saying that it automatically added
this permission on the user's behalf. We should do the same and automate this
process.

Once the account was given this access, I went back to the tomcat config manager
and it worked properly this time.

creator: cowwoc@bbs.darktech.org
text:
I stand corrected. The Tomcat configuration manager doesn't seem to work at all
for Log On settings. It always loses any settings in the Log On tab no matter
what I do; though the bit about giving a user "run as service" permission is
still important if we are to ever make this work.

Gili, it's been more than a year since this issue was filed, and evidently no
one cares (no votes, comments, emails on either mailing list, nothing).  Do you
care enough to provide an enhancement path to the service configuration manager?

The issue, at least with the latest tomcat5w.exe is that it does not display the current settings, the display always indicates a local system account even when another account is configured.

I have confirmed that the user settings entered are used, even if they are not displayed.

Tomcat uses Commons Daemon to provide the service wrapper. I have created https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DAEMON-126 to track this
